title: Now he wants to hold her hand! Why 'sulky' Donald Trump suddenly turns to Melania - by body language expert
text:

One positive thing about Donald Trump is that he does give good body language. 
When he's winning we get 'Alpha Trump': puffed up, smiling, squirming with righteousness and performing his signature I-O-L hand gesture ritual over and over again to emphasise the fact that he is not to be disagreed with. 
He is also a solitary beast, preferring to walk alone like the entrepreneurial business guru rather than holding on to anyone's hand unless there is a slope around to walk down and unless his co-stroller's name is Theresa May. US President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump hold hands - after he dropped her hand yesterday (Photo: Getty Images) Trump drops Melania's hand just hours before 
Appeal court REJECTS Donald Trump's emergency bid to restore his travel ban US President Donald Trump 'sulks' (Photo: REUTERS) 
Unlike his predecessors he seems to revel in his status-solitude, generally not wanting to share the limelight via any smoochy, romantic poses with his wife. 
But then there is Trump when he doesn't get his way. We saw 'Sulky-face Trump' during the debates with Clinton and now that stormy face has reappeared, along with a desire to hold hands with his wife. 
You can tell when Donald is not getting his way. The mouth clamps shut with the corners turned down and the chin pulled up, while his eyes lose that quasi-paternal crinkle that implies he is in total control as a leader, to take on a much colder look. US President Donald Trump's wife stays by his side (Photo: Getty Images) 
Sulking is great when you're nine years old, and because it is a relatively effective way of manipulating a transaction so that you sometimes do get your own way in terms of Xmas presents and treats it is often the weapon of choice of adults too. 
Who hasn't worked with the colleague or boss who sits in stony silence with a face like thunder, replying 'I'm fine' when asked if they're alright until the rest of the workforce buckles and gives in? 
And who hasn't seen the less-than-happy partner whose spouse adopts the 'smiling-by-proxy' look that Melania seems to be doing here? While Trump appears to show his displeasure in a way that would defy anyone to tell him to 'Hey, turn that frown upside down Donald!' his wife takes hold of his hand and comes forward to do all his smiling for him. Her eyes and teeth gleam and she is suddenly a very important part of the visual double-act again. Like us on Facebook
